titlepage.titleproper: College Hall Occupation Oral History Project, 1986
titlepage.subtitle: Finding Aid

titlepage.sponsor: Encoding funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: College Hall Occupation Oral History Project
did.abstract: Student demonstration. Includes interviews and papers.

bioghist.p: The College Hall Occupation Oral History Project was the work of two students enrolled in History 367b, Problems in American History: Autobiography, Biography, and Oral History in Twentieth Century America as taught by Maurice Isserman in spring 1986. The sixteen cassette tapes and two papers were given to the College Archives in the summer and fall of 1986 by the coordinators of the project, Donna Kenny '87 and Maureen Dooley Lawrence '87.

chronitem.event: Student/faculty rally and sit-in encouraging total divestment prior to the spring meeting of the Board of Trustees.
Trustees choose not to adopt the divestment proposal set forth by the Senate Ethical Investment Committee.

eventgrp.event: "Round-the-clock" sit-in outside the President's office by circa 200 students and faculty to protest the Trustees' decision.
Approximately 90 students spend the night in College Hall.
Approximately 150 students join the overnighters and 5:30 a.m. The protesters form human chains to block all entrances to College Hall. Employees are denied entrance to the building.
President Dunn refuses to have the protesters arrested.
Protesters hold a press conference announcing their position and reading statements of support for the occupation.

All-college meeting to discuss South Africa and the occupation of College Hall. Protesters send a group of "presidential delegates" to read a statement expressing their conviction that the takeover of College Hall was their only recourse.

chronitem.event: Protesters agree to negotiate with President Dunn. A small group of protesters begins a hunger strike.
Negotiations continue. Protesters hold a rally and announce the hunger strike to the public.
An agreement is reached between President Dunn, the Board of Trustees, and the protesters.
Occupation ends with a press conference and victory rally. Mar. 6, Thursday Required teach-in on South African-related issues and on relations between the Board of Trustees and the campus community.

accessrestrict.p: Donna Kenny's portion of the project consist of interviews with fourteen members of the administration, faculty, and staff and a paper based on the interviews. Many of these interviews are open for listening without restriction but in most cases permission from the interviewee is required before excerpts can be published in any way. Portions of Ms. Kenny's paper have been blocked out because she takes quotes from interviews that are restricted. Maureen Dooley Lawrence's portion of the project consists of four tapes of interviews with students participating in the occupation and a paper based on those interviews. All of the student interviews and Ms. Lawrence's paper are closed until July 1, 1991. At that time the tapes and paper will be made available with the names of the individuals removed.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please use the following format when citing materials from this collection:
College Hall Occupation Oral History Project, Box #, Smith College Archives.

processinfo.p: Processed by Maida Goodwin and Karen Eberhard.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: For a more detailed account of the occupation see the report prepared by the 1985-86 Committee on Community Policy (CCP) subcommittee dated October 1, 1986. See also issues of the student newspaper the Sophian during the spring of 1986 starting with the February 24th issue. The October, 23, 1986 issue followed the release of the CCP report. Additional material related to the occupation is available in the file on student demonstrations: 80.Dem 1986 CHO
